transcripts.text: and uh desaline was seemed to be in her prized.

tantoya is significant because she taught the greatest hero to ever live how to do hand-to-hand combat.  when he was a teenager how to shoot.  she taught him everything he knew.  you know because he was enslaved uh uh but she had come from a warrior background.

i don't recall seeing anywhere where tucson was beaten whereas desaline was constant.  his entire back was whooped with scars.  that healed and hurt again and healed and you know huge big blobs of scars all over his back.

And Dessalines, as opposed to Toussaint, did not have the love of the French military.  He had a deep understanding of the European exploitation.  He also had a deep understanding of the ruthlessness of the various European populations when they were taking out vengeance on the African population.

See, the difference between Toussaint and Dessalines, Toussaint wanted to make deals with the white supremacists.  Toussaint felt he was a military man.  He had some kind of camaraderie with the French.  He felt that he could make deals.  He was somewhat one of them.  They would respect him as a military man.  And that was his downfall.  Now, Dessalines, he knew it.  He's really the only modern African leader who understood that you cannot make deals with terrorists.  You can't make deals with white supremacy.  White supremacy is the ultimate form of terrorism.  And Dessalines was the only person who was smart enough to realize that.  And he got all the white supremacists off the island.

That's the story.  So he was enslaved African.  He was definitely beaten a lot.  He ended up being bought by a free black man.  So, you know, those assimilated Negroes could do some good things if they want.  His name was Jean-Baptiste Dessalines, the free black man who bought him.  and gave him his freedom.  But Desalines never forgot what slavery was about.
So what Desalines did is, you buried alive 500 Africans, he hung 500 French.  For everything that Rochambeau did, Desalines did the same thing.

Add up all of those different characteristics, the topography, the geography, the guerrilla warfare, the use of arson, et cetera, you begin to understand how and why the Africans on the island were able to prevail.
At the end of the war, it was really bloody.  And I think there was a point in time where Warshambul had killed thousands and he matched them, like head for head.

I mean, one of the raids I've learned about was a raid Dessalines undertook where they raided a French camp with just machetes.  Now imagine you're a heavily armed French camp and a bunch of dudes walks into your camp with just machetes and chop you up.  The level of bravery and arrogance almost that takes to go and face the French with just machetes.
The other piece to remember is you have St.  Lucia, Tobago and Martinique.
